channel.title: HL2 - Silent treatment
channel.description:
Hey guys, For my university course, I am studying the way that half-life deals with cutscenes, for my dissertation. Please get involved in the following discussion and see where it leads (discussion not strictly questionnaire) Thanks!
silent treatment In the half-life series, the player character, "Gordon Freeman' doesn't talk, the camera never turns to see the player and the game never splits into a cut-scene. Some games make a distinction between 'story line' moments and 'action' moments. How does losing control of your character during 'story line' moments affect your view of the 'story line' part of the game? In contrast, half-life deals with story by allowing you to always control your character from first-person, during every part of the game, How does this freedom make you feel? Gordon freeman famously doesn't speak. Do you feel like this allows your to transplant your own personality and internal voice onto the character, or do you feel like it makes the story lack clarity and make it frustrating?

item.title: HL2 - Silent treatment
item.dc:creator: Mack
item.description:
I think that the connection between the not talking and the cut-scene is very serious and deliberate. Both allow for us, as the gamer, to project ourselves into the character. Gordon not speaking means he never says anything that we wouldn’t say. I know that most of the time while I was playing, if someone said something to Gordon, I answered out loud! Having control in the cut scenes works in the exact same way, Gordon never made a move without us making it for him. The cut-scenes where we couldn’t move, like when the Hunter gets Alyx for example, were done so to exaggerate the feeling of helplessness and frustration of not being able to move, when we normally could have done something.
An interesting subject! Good luck!
Mack

item.title: HL2 - Silent treatment
item.dc:creator: MarshmallowRadiation
item.description:
I like how the game designers force the player to watch the cutscene while still giving the illusion of control. They can predict how players will act (e.g. hear a voice below you in the vents and look down to see two soldiers chatting about something important, a tunnel constricts your vision so you end up looking at a bridge, or have an NPC point to a cinematic event, etc.)

I think the illusion of freedom is nice, and Gordon’s silence is too in a way because sometimes I end up catching myself responding with my own voice and words Freeman’s Mind style.
